abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Gas Infrastructure
            Development Project for Government of Tunisia (GoT) were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, project sustainability
            was likely, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: GoT did not comply at the later stages of project
            implementation with its commitment to adjust electricity
            tariffs and Bank management was reluctant to enforce the
            corresponding covenants. Bank management and staff should
            strictly enforce compliance with critical covenants to
            prevent the project from departing from some of its
            institutional objectives as well as to preserve the
            Bank's credibility, irrespective of considerations such
            as closing dates. The conversion component of the project
            did not include a well-defined description and targets. As a
            result, only four (out of fourteen) industrial undertakings
            were able to convert their facilities to use gas. In
            general, the project design should very detailed and
            comprehensive. In particular, this project component should
            have explicitly defined, based on a sound survey, a
            realistic program and the type and number of conversions to
            be achieved each year. Detailed and comprehensive project
            description and implementation targets are essential. The
            lessons from previous gas projects in Tunisia, in particular
            those concerning pricing policies and compliance with the
            commitment to adjust tariffs, should have been taken into
            account in preparing and implementing the project. Under
            Loan 3418-TUN, the Bank should have required from GoT to
            increase power tariffs and lower retail prices for gas to
            economic levels, all as an up front condition for approval
            of the loan.

5079170.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management,Trade and integration

abstracts.cdata!:
Associated gas production from the
            El-Borma oil field is declining rapidly as this field nears
            depletion. As a result, the Gabes region, the main
            industrial center in southern Tunisia, will face a
            significant energy supply deficit by 1993, since it depends
            on this associated gas for fuel supply. Bank analyses have
            confirmed that it would be more economic to continue to
            supply Gabes and its region with natural gas rather than
            convert existing industries to fuel oil and transfer some of
            STEG's (Tunisian Company for Electricity and Gas) power
            generation facilities in Gabes further north on the TMP
            (Trans-Mediterranean Pipeline). The project will provide a
            least-cost energy supply alternative for Gabes and other gas
            markets along the pipeline route. A gas infrastructure
            network in the southern part of the country to facilitate
            domestic gas field development will be established. The
            increased use of natural gas in the industrial and premium
            fuels markets will be promoted. In addition, the project
            will develop a sound gas subsector strategy while
            rationalizing and strengthening the subsector's
            institutional model. A modern supervisory control and data
            acquisition (SCADA) system will be developed to enhance the
            security of the gas supply.
